title: Time detection in g.part5
body:
Hi Vincent!

As I told you, I am active on GGIR again. The past week I found something strange, so maybe it is better if you have a look on this changes before merging them.

When running g.part5 in my computer, it didn't detect the time correctly, I mean, day and night identification had no sense at all, with larger values on mean night accelerations than in day accelerations for some days.

I used debug() to look deeply into the code and I found that when using timebb to find a determined timestamp (when looking for sustained inactivity behaviors and when looking for day and night identification), the timestamp identified did not correspond with the timestamp the code was looking for. I assumed a misfunctioning due to the class of the objects, so I as.character() to change the class of timebb and it seems to work correctly now.

As I said, this was not happening before summer, so it is strange this error, please, confirm that the error is not happening only in my data (for any reason) before to merge these changes. 

Cheers,
Jairo

Sorry Vincent, I forgot to include this "metric" argument in g.part3 function, now this functionality is implemented so that user can select the metric from g.part3 and so on.

Cheers,

title: Issues #9 and #39
body:
Hi Vincent,

Here two small pull requests in one, sorry for doing them together.

For issue #9 , I have added the argument "metric" in some functions, so that now the user can select what metric should be used for estimations, making the code independent on ENMO.

For issue #39 , please, feel free to change the description of my contributions or whatever if you consider.

Thanks,
Jairo

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

title: Expandtests
body:
This pull request is a bit of mixture of new features. Sorry about that, next time I will try to make separate pull requests for separate functionalities. Below I have summarized the changes/additions I made:

- Codecov badge added to the README file. This tells us the extend to which the code is covered by tests
- Functions added to create dummy accelerometer file (csv) and a dummy sleeplog (csv), needed for testing
- Default IVIS_epochsize_seconds parameter updated from 30 to 3600, the metric is still not perfectly compatible with the originally published metric, but at least this is one step closer to the original design
- I condensed the amount of characters printed on screen when running g.calibrate and g.getmeta. The message ‘loading block’ will now only be printed once followed by just the numbers of the blocks separated by spaces rather than new lines.
- Function g.part5 is too long, so I made a beginning with moving parts of the code to separate functions: getfolderstructure() and identify_level() are new now.
- I replaced “Europe/London” in g.part5 by desiredtz, to make the function work for users outside the UK
- Data.frame output is now tidied up at the end of g.part5: entirely empty rows and columns are removed
I wrote tests and documentation files for all the new functions

The collection of tests GGIR currently has are a crude check that the code performs consistently. Next step will be to thoroughly review every single function and write additional tests to improve test coverage and make sure that all possible scenarios are covered.
Vincent

title: code expanded to handle condition when user has only 1 metric
body:
Hi Jairo, I noticed that  the new code is not able to handle the condition of a single metirc because the matrix collapses to a vector. I have added three lines to let it handle a single metric situation. 
Can you check and merge into master? Thanks, Vincent

title: MAD calculation, percentiles, levels and dayborder (and documentation updated)
body:
Hi Vincent,
I'll test on my own if it works correctly, thanks for your help and the opportunity of collaboration =)
Best,
Jairo

title: Mad calculation, percentiles, levels and dayborder
body:
Hi Vincent,

Sorry it took me more time than expected, but I am here with changes done (hopefully well-done).

Here a list of the changes I pulled:

Mean Amplitude Deviation (MAD) calculation (g.part2, g.analyse, g.applymetrics): as we discussed I have included the calculation of this metric till g.part2, for methodological papers. We were also discussing about the name of this metric, let me know if you want to change as you suggested.

qlevels and ilevels (g.part2): there was an issue with keepindex_46 and keep_index_28 in g.part2 and it only calculated percentiles and levels for the last metric marked as TRUE in the function call. I modified it to get percentiles and levels for all the metrics.

dayborder in g.part5: I also have included the argument "dayborder" in g.part5 in case the measurement starts after 0am the first day, now this first day would be included if meets the requirements.

First, I updated my branches with your changes to your master branch and now I am doing this pull request. I hope it all goes well, let me know if I have to fix something.

Best,
Jairo

title: Summary qlevels ilevels
body:
Hi Vincent,
I detected an issue in g.analyse. If you look at the summary data frame, you can see how the weighted percentiles (qlevels) and distribution of acceleration (ilevels) are only calculated for the last metric selected. This is because the keepindex_46 and the keepindex_48 variables store only the last indices, when the loop runs, the new values overwrites the previous ones. Here keepindex_46 and keepindex_48 are two matrices that store the indeces for each metric, so we can run a loop to calculate qlevels and ilevels for all the metrics selected.
I have tested it in some files and it works well.
